confusion_pairs.title: RTO vs RPO

a.definition: Maximum acceptable downtime (time to restore service).

b.definition: Maximum acceptable data loss (how far back you can roll).

bullets: RTO is time-focused; RPO is data-loss-focused.
Short RTO usually needs hot/warm site + automation.
Short RPO usually needs frequent snapshots/replication.

confusion_pairs.title: Incremental vs Differential Backups

a.definition: Backs up changes since the last backup (full or incremental).

b.definition: Backs up changes since the last full backup.

bullets: Incremental restores need: last full + every incremental since.
Differential restores need: last full + latest differential only.
Incremental saves space/time; differential often restores faster.

confusion_pairs.title: Snapshots vs Backups

a.definition: Point-in-time copy-on-write state (fast rollback, often same storage system).

b.definition: Independent copy stored separately for recovery (often offsite/immutable).

bullets: Snapshots are great for quick rollback, not a full disaster strategy alone.
Backups survive storage failure/ransomware better when isolated/immutable.
Best practice: snapshots for speed + backups for survivability.

confusion_pairs.title: Synchronous vs Asynchronous Replication

a.definition: Writes must commit to both sites before success (near-zero data loss).

b.definition: Primary commits first; updates replicate later (some data loss possible).

bullets: Sync replication lowers RPO but increases latency and needs strong links.
Async replication tolerates distance and latency but can lose recent writes.
Pick based on RPO/RTO and network realities.

confusion_pairs.title: Hot vs Warm vs Cold Sites

a.definition: Fully running duplicate environment; fastest recovery, highest cost.

b.definition: Warm: partially ready; Cold: space only. Slower recovery, cheaper.

bullets: Hot = minimal downtime; Warm = moderate downtime; Cold = long downtime.
Hot supports strict RTO; cold usually violates strict RTO.
Warm often needs restore + configuration before go-live.

confusion_pairs.title: UPS vs Generator

a.definition: Immediate short-term power + conditioning; bridges to generator.

b.definition: Longer-term backup power; has startup delay and needs fuel/maintenance.

bullets: UPS kicks in instantly; generator takes time to spin up.
UPS protects from sags/spikes; generator provides endurance.
Together they improve availability.

confusion_pairs.title: Tailgating vs Piggybacking

a.definition: Unauthorized person follows in without consent (victim unaware).

b.definition: Authorized person knowingly lets someone in (consent).

bullets: Both bypass physical access controls.
Mantraps/turnstiles/guards reduce both.
Training targets piggybacking; barriers target tailgating.

confusion_pairs.title: Deterrence vs Delay vs Detection

b.definition: Slow attackers and alert responders (locks, mantraps, alarms, sensors).

bullets: Deterrence changes behavior; delay buys time; detection triggers response.
Strong programs combine all three.
Delay without detection is pointless; detection without response is theater.

confusion_pairs.title: Tabletop vs Simulation vs Parallel/Failover Tests

a.definition: Discussion-based walk-through; low risk, validates plans and roles.

b.definition: Hands-on testing; higher realism (and risk), validates systems.

bullets: Tabletop is cheapest and safest; failover is most realistic.
Parallel runs DR alongside production; failover switches to DR.
Choose based on maturity and acceptable risk.

recovery.rto_rpo.rule: RTO = how long you can be down. RPO = how much data you can lose.
recovery.rto_rpo.micro_example: Payroll system: RTO 4h (must be back by noon), RPO 15m (can lose at most 15 minutes of entries).

recovery.point_in_time.rule: Point-in-time recovery means restoring data to an exact time (often via logs/snapshots).
recovery.point_in_time.micro_example: After accidental delete at 10:12, restore database to 10:10 snapshot and replay logs.

backups.full_incremental_differential.rule: Know restore chains: full+incrementals vs full+latest differential.
backups.full_incremental_differential.micro_example: If you used incrementals all week, you need Monday full + every daily incremental to restore.

backups.incremental.rule: Incremental = changes since last backup (full or incremental). Space-efficient, restore-chain longer.
backups.incremental.micro_example: Daily incrementals: Tue backup only includes changes since Monday.

backups.differential.rule: Differential = changes since last full. Gets larger over time, restores faster.
backups.differential.micro_example: Friday differential includes all changes since Monday full.

backups.snapshot.rule: Snapshots are fast rollback points, but not enough alone for disaster recovery.
backups.snapshot.micro_example: A VM snapshot helps after a bad patch; but if storage is encrypted by ransomware, snapshot may be hit too.

virtualization.snapshots.rule: VM snapshots are convenient for rollback, but don’t replace backups and can impact performance if kept long.
virtualization.snapshots.micro_example: Take snapshot before upgrade; delete/merge it after validation to avoid long-term delta growth.

backups.offsite_storage.rule: Offsite copies protect against site disasters and many local ransomware events.
backups.offsite_storage.micro_example: Keep an encrypted backup copy in a different region/cloud account.

backups.onsite_offsite.rule: Onsite is faster restore; offsite survives building/site loss. You typically need both.
backups.onsite_offsite.micro_example: NAS backup for quick restores + cloud copy for disasters.

backups.encryption.rule: Encrypt backups at rest and in transit; protect keys separately (key management).
backups.encryption.micro_example: Backups in cloud bucket are encrypted; restore requires KMS key + MFA-protected access.

key_management.backups.rule: Backups are only useful if you can decrypt them—treat keys as a critical dependency.
key_management.backups.micro_example: Store backup keys in HSM/KMS; test key recovery in DR exercises.

backups.frequency.rule: Backup frequency is driven by RPO and business impact, not vibes.
backups.frequency.micro_example: RPO 15m implies frequent snapshots/replication, not nightly backups.

backups.recovery_process.rule: A backup without a tested restore is an expensive wish. Validate restores regularly.
backups.recovery_process.micro_example: Quarterly: restore random server + verify application integrity and access.

recovery.restoration_order.rule: Restore order matters: identity/network first, then critical apps, then noncritical systems.
recovery.restoration_order.micro_example: Bring up AD/DNS + core network, then payment processing, then analytics.

availability.resilience.rule: Resilience = keep operating and recover quickly under stress; it’s architecture + process.
availability.resilience.micro_example: Zone outage occurs; traffic shifts; service degrades but stays up, then recovers fully.

availability.high_availability.rule: HA aims to minimize downtime via redundancy/failover; it doesn’t automatically guarantee zero data loss.
availability.high_availability.micro_example: Two web servers behind a load balancer: if one dies, users still get served.

ha.single_point_of_failure.rule: SPOF is any component whose failure stops the system. Remove SPOFs in critical paths.
ha.single_point_of_failure.micro_example: One database with no replica is an SPOF; add replication + failover.

ha.load_balancing.rule: Load balancing spreads client requests; it improves availability and performance but needs health checks.
ha.load_balancing.micro_example: LB routes traffic away from failed node based on health checks.

ha.clustering.rule: Clustering coordinates multiple nodes as one service (often with shared state/failover).
ha.clustering.micro_example: Database cluster uses quorum; if one node fails, others keep serving.

network.multipath.rule: Multipath networking uses redundant network paths to avoid outages and bottlenecks.
network.multipath.micro_example: Two ISPs + automatic failover routing keeps remote offices online.

site.geographic_dispersion.rule: Geographic dispersion reduces correlated risk (same flood/earthquake/power grid).
site.geographic_dispersion.micro_example: Primary in Dhaka, DR in Chattogram to avoid single regional disaster.

site.hot_warm_cold.rule: Hot is fastest and most expensive; warm is moderate; cold is slow and cheap.
site.hot_warm_cold.micro_example: Banking core needs hot site; internal wiki might tolerate cold site.

site.warm_site.rule: Warm site has partial infrastructure; expects restore/config before use.
site.warm_site.micro_example: Servers and network exist, but data must be restored and apps started during incident.

recovery.site_selection.rule: Pick DR site type by RTO/RPO, budget, and how critical the service is.
recovery.site_selection.micro_example: Customer checkout system: warm/hot; marketing blog: cold.

site.selection.rule: Site selection considers distance, connectivity, risk profile, and legal/compliance requirements.
site.selection.micro_example: Choose region with low flood risk and strong connectivity to primary site.

power.ups_generator.rule: UPS provides instant bridge power; generator provides endurance after startup delay.
power.ups_generator.micro_example: UPS keeps servers alive for 5–15 minutes until generator stabilizes.

testing.tabletop.rule: Tabletop exercises validate plans/roles and find process gaps with low operational risk.
testing.tabletop.micro_example: DR team walks through ransomware scenario and identifies missing contact lists.

testing.simulation.rule: Simulations test technical execution under controlled conditions; more realistic than tabletop.
testing.simulation.micro_example: Simulate datacenter outage in lab; practice restore + traffic cutover.

testing.parallel.rule: Parallel testing runs DR systems alongside production without switching users; validates readiness safely.
testing.parallel.micro_example: Bring up DR site and run test transactions while production continues.

testing.failover.rule: Failover testing actually switches production to DR. Highest confidence, highest risk.
testing.failover.micro_example: Cut traffic to DR region for 30 minutes during maintenance window.

response_recovery.process.rule: Recovery isn’t just tech: comms, ownership, and escalation paths must be defined.
response_recovery.process.micro_example: Incident bridge call + status updates + approval to invoke DR runbook.

physical.layers.defense_in_depth.rule: Use layers: perimeter → entry → interior → sensitive areas. Each layer adds deterrence/delay/detection.
physical.layers.defense_in_depth.micro_example: Fence + badge access + mantrap + locked server room + rack locks.

physical.deterrence_delay.rule: Deterrence discourages; delay buys time; detection triggers response. Combine them.
physical.deterrence_delay.micro_example: Bollards deter vehicle ramming; mantrap delays; alarms detect.

physical.detect.rule: Detection is about knowing something happened (sensors/alarms/cameras) early enough to act.
physical.detect.micro_example: Door sensor triggers alarm + camera snapshot sent to security desk.

physical.prevent.rule: Prevent controls stop access outright (locks, access control vestibules, barriers).
physical.prevent.micro_example: Badge reader + locked turnstile prevents unauthorized entry.

physical.response.rule: Response turns detection into action: guards, dispatch, incident procedures.
physical.response.micro_example: Alarm triggers security guard dispatch and badge access is temporarily frozen.

physical.controls.bollards.rule: Bollards protect against vehicle threats; they’re a perimeter delay/prevent control.
physical.controls.bollards.micro_example: Install bollards in front of lobby to reduce vehicle ramming risk.

physical.controls.access_control_vestibu.rule: Access control vestibule/mantrap limits entry to one person at a time to stop tailgating.
physical.controls.access_control_vestibu.micro_example: Two-door vestibule: first door locks before second opens after identity check.

physical.anti_tailgating.rule: Stop tailgating/piggybacking with mantraps, turnstiles, guards, and user training.
physical.anti_tailgating.micro_example: Employee refuses to 'hold the door' for an unknown person without a badge.

physical.controls.access_badges.rule: Badges are convenient but can be cloned/borrowed; combine with PIN/biometric for sensitive areas.
physical.controls.access_badges.micro_example: Badge + PIN required for data center; badge alone for office floor.

physical.attacks.rfid_cloning.rule: RFID cloning attacks copy badge IDs. Mitigate with stronger badges, encryption, and multi-factor entry.
physical.attacks.rfid_cloning.micro_example: Attacker scans a badge in elevator and clones it; mantrap + PIN blocks entry.

physical.controls.video_surveillance.rule: CCTV is detection + forensics, not prevention alone. Pair it with access controls and response.
physical.controls.video_surveillance.micro_example: CCTV shows who entered; badge logs show which credential was used.

physical.controls.cameras.motion_detecti.rule: Motion detection reduces noise and highlights events; ensure it doesn’t become blind under heavy traffic.
physical.controls.cameras.motion_detecti.micro_example: After-hours motion alerts security; during day it records without alerting.

physical.controls.sensors.rule: Sensors provide detection: choose type based on environment and threat (IR, microwave, ultrasonic, pressure).
physical.controls.sensors.micro_example: Pressure mat in restricted hallway triggers alarm when stepped on after hours.

physical.controls.sensors.infrared.rule: Infrared sensors detect heat/motion; good for after-hours but can be affected by ambient heat sources.
physical.controls.sensors.infrared.micro_example: IR sensor alerts on movement in server room at night.

physical.controls.sensors.microwave.rule: Microwave sensors detect movement by reflected waves; can cover larger areas but may penetrate walls.
physical.controls.sensors.microwave.micro_example: Warehouse perimeter uses microwave motion detection with tuned sensitivity.

physical.controls.sensors.ultrasonic.rule: Ultrasonic sensors use sound waves; can be sensitive to airflow and environmental noise.
physical.controls.sensors.ultrasonic.micro_example: Small equipment room uses ultrasonic sensor for intrusion detection.

physical.controls.sensors.pressure.rule: Pressure sensors/mats detect weight/steps; simple but can be triggered by carts or heavy objects.
physical.controls.sensors.pressure.micro_example: Pressure mat alerts when someone enters a restricted corridor.

physical.controls.ids_alarms.rule: Intrusion detection + alarms must connect to response (dispatch). Alerts without action are useless.
physical.controls.ids_alarms.micro_example: Door forced open triggers alarm and calls security company.

physical.controls.security_guards.rule: Guards add deterrence and response; combine with logs and procedures for consistency.
physical.controls.security_guards.micro_example: Guard checks badges and escorts visitors to server room.

physical.controls.safe.rule: Safes protect critical media/keys. Choose rating and anchor it; access should be logged.
physical.controls.safe.micro_example: Store backup tapes in a fire-rated safe with dual control access.

physical.attacks.environmental.rule: Environmental attacks include fire, water, temperature, and power disruptions. Plan controls + DR.
physical.attacks.environmental.micro_example: HVAC failure overheats servers; sensors alert and failover triggers.

physical.attacks.brute_force.rule: Brute-force physical attacks target locks/doors/racks. Use strong locks, reinforced frames, and monitoring.
physical.attacks.brute_force.micro_example: Server racks have locking doors; security monitors access logs and cameras.

physical.controls.cost_tradeoff.rule: Physical controls are risk-to-cost tradeoffs: spend more where impact is highest.
physical.controls.cost_tradeoff.micro_example: Data center gets mantrap + CCTV; office pantry just needs basic locks.

capacity_planning.people_tech_infra.rule: Resilience is also staffing and process: people, tech, and infrastructure capacity all matter.
capacity_planning.people_tech_infra.micro_example: During incident, lack of on-call staff delays recovery even if DR systems exist.

scalability.elasticity.rule: Scalability handles growth; elasticity auto-adjusts resources up/down with demand.
scalability.elasticity.micro_example: Auto-scaling adds instances during peak and removes them afterward.

risk.attack_surface.rule: Attack surface is everything that can be attacked (services, endpoints, access paths). Reduce exposure.
risk.attack_surface.micro_example: Close unused ports and remove legacy protocols to shrink attack surface.

risk.blaster_radius.rule: Blast radius is how far damage spreads. Segmentation and least privilege reduce it.
risk.blaster_radius.micro_example: Compromised workstation can't reach payment DB due to network segmentation.

architecture.platform_diversity.rule: Platform diversity can reduce monoculture risk but increases operational complexity.
architecture.platform_diversity.micro_example: Using two hypervisors reduces single-vendor risk but needs more skills and tooling.

architecture.multicloud.rule: Multicloud can reduce vendor lock-in and improve resilience, but increases complexity and misconfig risk.
architecture.multicloud.micro_example: Critical service runs active-active across two clouds with consistent IAM and logging.

backups.nearline.rule: Nearline storage is not instant like online, but faster than offline; used for cost-effective retention.
backups.nearline.micro_example: Archived backups stored in nearline tier restore in hours, not seconds.

backups.storage_tiers.rule: Storage tiers trade cost vs speed: hot/online, warm/nearline, cold/archive.
backups.storage_tiers.micro_example: Daily backups on warm tier; yearly archives on cold tier.

backups.journaling.rule: Journaling/log shipping enables fine-grained recovery (point-in-time) beyond basic backups.
backups.journaling.micro_example: Database ships transaction logs to standby so you can restore to a specific minute.

backups.replication.sync_async.rule: Replication choice is an RPO/RTO decision: sync for low RPO, async for distance and lower cost.
backups.replication.sync_async.micro_example: Sync within same metro; async across continents.

backups.replication.synchronous.rule: Synchronous replication minimizes data loss but adds latency and requires robust connectivity.
backups.replication.synchronous.micro_example: Writes commit only when both sites acknowledge.

backups.replication.asynchronous.rule: Asynchronous replication tolerates distance/latency but risks losing recent writes.
backups.replication.asynchronous.micro_example: Primary acknowledges writes immediately; replica catches up shortly after.

confidentiality.backups.rule: Backups often contain the crown jewels; protect confidentiality with encryption + access controls.
confidentiality.backups.micro_example: Restrict backup operators; enable MFA and encrypt backup archives.

continuity.coop.rule: COOP (continuity of operations) keeps mission-critical functions running during disruption.
continuity.coop.micro_example: Alternate site and procedures allow payroll and emergency communications to continue.
